corrected_calculations.note: CORRECTED: Efficiency gain directly translates to mass reduction (1:1 ratio)

sai_qbo_feedback_loop.issue: Analysis assumes static QBO, ignoring SAI-induced feedback
sai_qbo_feedback_loop.mechanism: Aerosol heating → stratospheric warming → QBO disruption
sai_qbo_feedback_loop.impact: Operational strategy would disrupt its own control variable
sai_qbo_feedback_loop.implication: Results represent idealized sensitivity, not operational viability

neural_network_overfitting.problem: 96 training samples insufficient for 4-layer neural network
neural_network_overfitting.consequence: Core quantitative predictions may be artifacts

multi_latitude_confounding.problem: Tropical QBO signal correlated with subtropical-dominated forcing
multi_latitude_confounding.limitation: Results specific to GLENS setup, may not generalize
multi_latitude_confounding.scope: Cannot isolate pure tropical QBO-SAI physics

small_dataset_size.statistical_power: Limited power for detecting small effects

methodological_constraints.model_dependence: Results specific to GLENS CESM1-WACCM simulations
methodological_constraints.feedback_free_assumption: Analysis assumes no SAI-induced QBO changes

interpretation_bounds.operational_applicability: Results do NOT support operational SAI strategies
interpretation_bounds.scientific_scope: Sensitivity analysis within idealized model constraints

practical_implications.operational_relevance: LIMITED due to feedback loop disruption

mechanism_hypothesis.proposed: Westerly QBO phases enhance aerosol transport efficiency
mechanism_hypothesis.caveat: Mechanism would be disrupted by SAI-induced heating

scientific_value.contribution: Demonstrates QBO sensitivity in idealized conditions
scientific_value.limitation: Results not applicable to real-world SAI deployment
scientific_value.future_work: Requires models with interactive SAI-QBO coupling
